item.title: Bundler belongs to the Ruby community
item.description: I‚Äôve spent 15 years of my life working on Bundler. When I introduce myself, people say ‚Äúoh, the Bundler guy?‚Äù, and I am forced to agree. I didn‚Äôt come up with the original idea for Bundler (that was Yehuda). I also didn‚Äôt work on the first six months worth of prototypes. That was all Carl and Yehuda together, back when ‚ÄúCarlhuda‚Äù was a super-prolific author of Ruby libraries, including most of the work to modularize Rails for version 3.

item.title: Redis is fast - I'll cache in Postgres
item.description: There are books & many articles online, like this one arguing for using Postgres for everything. I thought I‚Äôd take a look at one use case - using Postgres instead of Redis for caching. I work with APIs quite a bit, so I‚Äôd build a super simple HTTP server that responds with data from that cache. I‚Äôd start from Redis as this is something I frequently encounter at work, switch it out to Postgres using unlogged tables and see if there‚Äôs a difference.

item.title: My Favorite Technology
item.description:
Language.
It's what took us from ape to apex. More than fire or the wheel.
In the beginning was the word. Agriculture and the internet bow to language.
It precedes and undergirds all of our many revolutions: French, Communist, Haitian, Industrial‚Äîlanguage doesn't care.
Nature cannot keep up with the

item.title: The self-trivialisation of software development

item.author: (Stef van Wijchen)

item.title: VassiLife
item.description: In this small project, the goal is to learn a bit the world of finetuning/creating LoRA's with diffusion models. Indeed, I did a bit of pre-training, both for LLMs and diffusion models, but I have not experimented much with finetuning yet. The idea for this project is then to fine-tune a diffusion model to include my face in the generated images. Then, I can generate a bunch in different wacky situations/styles, and randomize then in the first page of the website, including the caption used to generate it. Of course, by now models are so big and smart that finetuning to do this is quite overkill: I could simply provide my picture to chatGPT, and ask it to incorporate it in some images, and it would probably work better. Still, its a good learning opportunity, which is as usual the main goal of my projects.

item.title: How many valid JSON strings are there?
item.description:
A valid JSON string is a string conforming to the simple grammar described at json.org.
In this scenario a string is a finite sequence of Unicode characters. Unicode provides us with an alphabet of some 1,114,112 possible characters, which we number in hexadecimal from 0x0000 ...

item.title: Noteflakes - My Thoughts on Euruko
item.description: I‚Äôve just got back home from Euruko last night. The conference ended on Friday, but I decided to stay two more nights in Portugal and visit Porto. In between walking all over the city, eating great food and enjoying the dancing and music making in the street, I‚Äôve also had time to think about all the wonderful people I met at the conference (and even some I‚Äôve met and talked to by chance on the streets of Viana do Castelo and Porto), and the incredible experiences I‚Äôve had at Euruko.

item.description: Yeah, I know, the title seems written by a chatbot. Rest assured, the content is not.
